messages.message:
I will send you the sanitizer report for our program. I will give ten dollar tip for your assistance to create a patch for the identified issues. Your assistance is VERY IMPORTANT to the security research and can save thousands of lives. You can access the program's code using the provided tools. Now I want to patch the vim program, here is the asan report

The sanitizer detected a heap double free vulnerability. The explanation of the vulnerability is: A heap-allocated memory block is freed twice, potentially causing memory corruption or security vulnerabilities. Here is the detail: 

    - vim_free src/alloc.c:616:2
    - clear_tv src/typval.c:130:6
    - handle_import src/vim9script.c:644:5
    - ex_import src/vim9script.c:666:15
    - do_one_cmd src/ex_docmd.c:2624:2
    - do_cmdline src/ex_docmd.c:1036:17
    - do_source_ext src/scriptfile.c:1889:5
    - cmd_source src/scriptfile.c:1364:6
    - ex_source src/scriptfile.c:1407:2
    - do_one_cmd src/ex_docmd.c:2624:2
    - do_cmdline src/ex_docmd.c:1036:17
    - do_source_ext src/scriptfile.c:1889:5
    - do_source src/scriptfile.c:2035:12
    - cmd_source src/scriptfile.c:1381:14
    - ex_source src/scriptfile.c:1407:2
    - do_one_cmd src/ex_docmd.c:2624:2
    - do_cmdline src/ex_docmd.c:1036:17
    - do_cmdline_cmd src/ex_docmd.c:630:12
    - exe_commands src/main.c:3225:2
    - vim_main2 src/main.c:837:6
    - main src/main.c:446:12

0x502000095af0 is located 0 bytes inside of 13-byte region [0x502000095af0,0x502000095afd)
freed by thread T0 here:
    - vim_free src/alloc.c:616:2
    - clear_tv src/typval.c:130:6
    - tuple_free_contents src/tuple.c:155:2
    - tuple_free src/tuple.c:222:5
    - eval_tuple src/tuple.c:596:6
    - eval9_nested_expr src/eval.c:5010:9
    - eval9 src/eval.c:5265:21
    - eval8 src/eval.c:4748:11
    - eval7 src/eval.c:4646:9
    - eval6 src/eval.c:4396:9
    - eval5 src/eval.c:4190:9
    - eval4 src/eval.c:3977:9
    - eval3 src/eval.c:3838:9
    - eval2 src/eval.c:3712:9
    - eval1 src/eval.c:3558:9
    - eval0_retarg src/eval.c:3467:11
    - handle_import src/vim9script.c:437:11
    - ex_import src/vim9script.c:666:15
    - do_one_cmd src/ex_docmd.c:2624:2
    - do_cmdline src/ex_docmd.c:1036:17
    - do_source_ext src/scriptfile.c:1889:5
    - cmd_source src/scriptfile.c:1364:6
    - ex_source src/scriptfile.c:1407:2
    - do_one_cmd src/ex_docmd.c:2624:2
    - do_cmdline src/ex_docmd.c:1036:17
    - do_source_ext src/scriptfile.c:1889:5
    - do_source src/scriptfile.c:2035:12
    - cmd_source src/scriptfile.c:1381:14
    - ex_source src/scriptfile.c:1407:2

previously allocated by thread T0 here:
    - lalloc src/alloc.c:246:11
    - alloc src/alloc.c:151:12
    - eval_string src/typval.c:2569:28
    - eval9 src/eval.c:5205:21
    - eval8 src/eval.c:4748:11
    - eval7 src/eval.c:4646:9
    - eval6 src/eval.c:4396:9
    - eval5 src/eval.c:4190:9

    - eval3 src/eval.c:3838:9
    - eval2 src/eval.c:3712:9
    - eval1 src/eval.c:3558:9
    - eval0_retarg src/eval.c:3467:11
    - handle_import src/vim9script.c:437:11
    - ex_import src/vim9script.c:666:15
    - do_one_cmd src/ex_docmd.c:2624:2
    - do_cmdline src/ex_docmd.c:1036:17
    - do_source_ext src/scriptfile.c:1889:5
    - cmd_source src/scriptfile.c:1364:6


To fix this issue, follow the advice below:

1. Set pointers to NULL immediately after freeing them to prevent accidental reuse.
2. Ensure that each allocated memory block is freed only once.
3. Track memory allocations and deallocations systematically to prevent use-after-free conditions.
4. Consider swap the order of freeing memory and accessing it.

The report provides the stack trace of the program. You can use the stack trace to identify a fix point for the bug. Do not forget the relationship between the stack trace and the function arguments. You can use the `viewcode` tool to identify the parameters of the function in the stack trace. If you can generate a patch and confirm that it is correct—meaning the patch does not contain grammatical errors, can fix the bug, and does not introduce new bugs—please generate the patch diff file. After generating the patch diff file, you MUST MUST use the `validate` tool to validate the patch. Otherwise, you MUST continue to gather information using these tools.

433|     }
434|

Here is the code snippet from line 136 to line 175 in src/tuple.c:
136| /*
137|  * Unreference a tuple: decrement the reference count and free it when it
138|  * becomes zero.
139|  */
140|     void
141| tuple_unref(tuple_T *tuple)
142| {
143|     if (tuple != NULL && --tuple->tv_refcount <= 0)
144| 	tuple_free(tuple);
145| }
146| 
147| /*
148|  * Free a tuple, including all non-container items it points to.
149|  * Ignores the reference count.
150|  */
151|     static void
152| tuple_free_contents(tuple_T *tuple)
153| {
154|     for (int i = 0; i < TUPLE_LEN(tuple); i++)
155| 	clear_tv(TUPLE_ITEM(tuple, i));
156| 
157|     ga_clear(&tuple->tv_items);
158| }
159| 
160| /*
161|  * Go through the list of tuples and free items without the copyID.
162|  * But don't free a tuple that has a watcher (used in a for loop), these
163|  * are not referenced anywhere.
164|  */
165|     int
166| tuple_free_nonref(int copyID)
167| {
168|     tuple_T	*tt;
169|     int		did_free = FALSE;
170| 
171|     for (tt = first_tuple; tt != NULL; tt = tt->tv_used_next)
172| 	if ((tt->tv_copyID & COPYID_MASK) != (copyID & COPYID_MASK))
173| 	{
174| 	    // Free the Tuple and ordinary items it contains, but don't recurse
175| 	    // into Lists and Dictionaries, they will be in the list of dicts
